title: Before 1 January 2020, will the UK and the EU adopt an agreement on which customs territory Northern Ireland will be located in after the end of any Brexit transition period?
possible_answers: Yes, the United Kingdom's customs territory only
Yes, the European Union's customs territory only
Yes, a single customs territory that includes both the European Union and the United Kingdom
preds: Updating from 97/1/1/1. Withdrawal Bill has passed but "MPs also backed the timetable for further debate on the bill over three days when they return after the Christmas recess - on 7, 8 and 9 January." [1] GG everyone! [1] https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-50870939

Following the UK election the UK will be able to pass the legislation to leave the UK. This may or may not be completed before 1 Jan 2020 (probably 90% likely it will not be done before January) but the question is not about an agreement to leave the EU, but an agreement on the future customs status of NI. 
The customs status of NI does not automatically change when the UK leaves the EU, but it might change when a EU/UK future trade agreement is settled. The time table for a EU/UK future trade agreement is some time after the UK has left the UK, the UK wants that to happen during 2020. Although the UK WA mentions the future customs status of NI what is described lacks legal clarity, and it is questionable if it really answers this forecast. Specifically the UK just saying that NI will remain in the UK Customs territory when NI customs will appear be aligned in both regulations and tariffs to the EU Customs territory does not make sense (except as a political description as something that is actually quite different). This is shown by BJ claiming that no Customs checks between GB and NI will take place, and his ministers and trade experts saying that checks will have to take place.  It would seem that no customs checks between NI and GB would only be possible if the GB customs territory and EU customs territory had the same rules and tariffs.
I don't think this will get any further before the end of January at the very earliest.

Updating from 77/8/7/8. UK Parliament dissolved today for the general election [1], which is to happen on 12 Dec 2019. [1] https://www.parliament.uk/business/news/2019/november/the-house-has-dissolved/
Even BJ is talking about "getting Brexit done" by mid-January. (And that assumes he remains PM and has a majority to get his deal thru Parliament).
An update. Bj interviewed by BBC said WAB by "mid-january". So presumably even he thinks it can't be done before Jan 2020. (But he has been wrong before)
Agree with @Tetbury that given the UK election on 12 December, there probably won't be enough time afterward to pass and formally adopt the WAB.

The results of the UK GE will probably not be known before 16th Dec. Assuming Parliament will not be sitting for a Xmas break  there will not be many days available to form a new government and pass the WAB (7 including the weekend? plus 4 after Xmas) and even if there are I am not sure if the EU Parliament will be open to pass the legislation required.  Its quite likely (30% to 50% that there is hung parliament which will slow things down as well. Its almost certain that at least some ministers will have to be appointed to replace those voted out. So the timetable looks very tight even if BJ remains PM.
Damn it I wish this thing had alerts I forgot I had a prediction here

Updating from 50/17/16/17 on passage of time and the acceptance of a new Brexit delay until 31 Jan 2020. Govt now is aiming for general election on the week of 9-12 Dec 2019, and that would leave only 2 weeks before year-end break to fully solve Brexit. Still, if there is a major electoral victory by the Tories, they could conceivably pass Boris's current deal quickly, maybe with the symbolic start date of 1 Jan 2020 --- so I will leave the Y/N split at 35/65 for now (I had it at 50/50 before).

Today it became very clear that there is some doubt that what status of NI's customs territory would be in the WA B. Several MPs pointed out that if full customs paperwork and possibly in the future tarriffs (if for example the UK failed to get a FTA and went to WTO terms, while NI remained aligned to EU customs, goods from/to NI/GB would have to pay tariffs) then NI was not part of the UK customs territory.

The new withdrawal agreement that Johnson struck with the EU last week was met with fierce opposition by U.K lawmakers — in particular the DUP, as well as the main opposition Labour Party.

https://www.instituteforgovernment.org.uk/explainers/brexit-deal-northern-ireland-protocol

The court has ruled that BJ's deal is legal as far as the NI customs is concerned. So that seems to mean Brexit happens by 31st Dec NI will be in the UK Customs Territory and not in the EU Customs Territory,  So the question is will BJ's Bexit deal be passed. My guess there is a 50% chance that it will be passed by 31st Dec.

The question of what BJ's WA means in terms of NI customs territory comes to court today. Basically the court will have to decide if the WA calling NI to be part of UK customs territory when the WA says NI will have different rules so that it conforms to EU customs is legally coherent   Under the current law, Section 55 of the Taxation (Cross-border Trade) Act 2018 prevents Northern Ireland from having difference customs rules than the rest of the UK.  So after today there could be some clarity on this question, but changes to Section 55 might be needed, but if they are, then we might find out if calling a geographic area a customs territory if different rules apply in different parts is allowed.

https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/oct/17/how-is-boris-johnson-brexit-deal-different-from-theresa-may "Northern Ireland will remain legally in the UK customs territory but practically in the EU customs unions. There will therefore be no customs checks on the border but tariffs will be payable on certain commercial goods."

I am very unclear how this question could be scored. 
If the WA is passed by all concerned then NI would (according to Barnier) legally leave the EU Customs Union with the rest of the UK and continue to be part of the UK Customs territory.  The problem is that the normal definition of a Customs Territory is that it has no internal customs, while the proposed arrangement does have internal customs for goods entering NI from the UK. I guess the get around is that the customs on entering NI from GB are EU Customs being carried out by the UK on behalf of the EU. I think that there is a 20% chance that a Brexit WA will be passed by the end of this year,   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Customs_territory

The FT reports that the UK proposals on this question are baffling the EU. If they are baffling the EU then I feel no shame in  being baffled as well but I my previous comments were far from clear so I am having another try at clarity. First point is I am pretty sure this will not be sorted out by 31st Oct. There is some chance (20%? 10%) that BJ and the EU may have agreed something by 31 Dec. But whatever BJ and EU could agree will probably (60% to 80%) to rejected by the UK Parliament because it will appear to cross the red lines of one group on MPs or another. So that would seems to suggest that a "Yes" could be somewhere in the range 2% to 12%.  The problem I then have is that none of the possible "Yes" answers seems to fit the options offered to this question.  The way the media are reporting what they believe BJ is asking for is for NI to be legally be in the UK Customs territory, but administratively in the EU Customs territory.  I don't expect the media to be particularly careful to only use legal definitions of terms like Customs Territory, but if the normal meaning of a Customs territory is as per the wikipedia entry below 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Customs_territory
its hard to see how NI could be considered to be legally in the UK Customs territory if it has different rates and rules to the rest of the UK, and there are checks and tariffs on trade between NI and GB. This is like calling a horse an elephant.  There seems a better logical case for saying that NI would be in the EU Customs territory if it has duties and rules that lined up with those of the EU and it had no checks on moving goods across the border. The problem with this option is that it seems that for political reasons BJ cannot say that NI is remaining in the EU Customs territory. If the UK Government explicitly say that NI is NOT going to be in the EU Customs territory, but there is some new type of relationship between the EU and NI its a bit presumptuous for forecasters to argue that the UK Government is wrong and that NI is in the EU Customs territory. This is the equivalent to there being two horses, but BJ is calling one of them an elephant.  We seem to entered Alice's Wonderland where words mean whatever you want them to mean. Anyone else got any ideas how this question should be answered? Should we follow the wikipedia definition of a Customs territory, or what BJ seems to want it to mean?  If we decide that NI would remain in the EU Customs territory in spite of what the UK Government calls the relationship, do we have accept that NI is in the UK Customs territory because BJ chooses to claim it is, when according to the normal meaning of the term it is not?

Its possible that as reported in some of the UK media, BJ's revised (secret) proposal will be for NI to be a separate customs territory that has the same tariffs as the EU, but is not part of the EU Customs Union. Legally as I understand it the EU Customs territory and the NI Customs territory would have a Customs Union, but they would each be separate customs territories. In the same way that Turkey is not part of The EU Customs Union (a customs territory for EU members only) but has has A Customs Union between Turkey's Customs territory and the EU. Technically there is a difference between the EU Customs Union that has FTAs with 3rd countries like Canada and Japan and the EU/Turkey Customs Union which has no FTAs with 3rd counties.  So my understanding is that if NI were to be fully aligned with the EU regarding customs it would not legally be located in the EU's Customs Territory, but would have a Customs Union with the EU's Customs Territory as Turkey does. But if NI had different tariffs to the remainder of the UK it would also not be in the UK Customs Territory either. So this question should have another option - "Yes, its own NI Customs Territory", as it does not have this option I am including that option in the "No" box.     https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union

Yesterday's BJ and Varadkar meeting suggested that BJ may be looking to change his ideas on the NI customs arrangements. I have seen no detail so I am just guessing that either NI will remain in the EU Customs territory (as the EU previously proposed) or that the whole UK will remain in the EU Customs Area. 
The obvious political problems are that many (but not all) Leave voters would not be happy especially if the UK was to be in a single customs area with the EU. Leave voters would probably be less bothered if NI was in a Customs area with the EU, but the DUP would be be unhappy. (In today's real world yesterdays allies are dropped when the populist leaders no longer need them.) 
As many businesses throughout the UK are warning BJ that with the import duties proposed they would not be viable it could be that BJ is having second thoughts. On the other hand the "pathway" could lead nowhere.

I'm assuming this means no deal or article 50 extension? If not i need to change. 100% due to recent break down in talks. Only 22 days before deadline for extension or impending no deal. Either way no "agreement" will be made.

Even if the EU were to agree to the UK's proposal without negotiating further, it remains to be seen if the complex infrastructure required to carry out customs checks could be ready to enter operation by the end of the month - Johnson has repeatedly promised, "do or die", to take Britain out of the EU on October 31. Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar told Johnson later on Wednesday that "the proposals do not fully meet the agreed objectives of the backstop", the Irish government said. The EU's lead Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier gave a guarded welcome to the plan as he arrived at the European Parliament to brief its Brexit steering group. "There is progress, but to be frank a lot of work still needs to be done," Barnier said. Guy Verhofstadt, the head of the parliament's steering group, said the initial assessment of "nearly every member" of the committee "was not positive at all" because the proposal does not offer enough safeguards to Ireland. He suggested the UK offer was not a serious attempt at reaching a deal but an effort to shift blame for failure to Brussels - a concern harboured by many in Brussels since Johnson took office vowing to take Britain out of the EU on October 31.
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/10/britain-publishes-brexit-proposal-191002144925437.html Factbox: Key points from UK PM Johnson's Brexit offer 5 Min Read LONDON (Reuters) - Prime Minister Boris Johnson unveiled what he said would be his final offer to the European Union for an amended Brexit deal, warning that if the proposals are not accepted Britain will leave the bloc at the end of the month without a divorce deal. Below are the key points from the offer:
NORTHERN IRISH BACKSTOP REMOVED: “Our proposed compromise removes the so-called ‘backstop’ in the previous Withdrawal Agreement,” Johnson said.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-plans-factbox/factbox-key-points-from-uk-pm-johnsons-brexit-offer-idUSKBN1WH1O5

If BJ's current proposal (as currently reported) to the EU was agreed by all parties before 1 Jan 2020 then NI would be in a UK only customs territory at the end of the transition period. How likely is this? I have not seen the full legal text, but the summary released says that the NI Parliament would need to agree to some of the conditions (regulatory agreement with EU rules in some areas) while these conditions are not the customs territory I would think that the deal as a whole would depend on all parties agreeing all of the conditions. As a consequence of NI having regulatory alignment presumably NI would still come under the European Court of Justice, while the remainder of the UK does not, it appears to me that this would make NI substantially different to the rest of the UK.   
As the NI Parliament  (NI Assembly) has not been operating since March 2017 I would assume that the NI Assembly needs to be up and running again in order to agree to the BJ proposal. 
The reasons the NI Assembly is not sitting are to do with the odd way that that it operates. It requires power sharing and consensus to operate and can only agree to anything if consensus exists. This appears to mean that under BJ's proposal any group in the Assembly can refuse to agree to the regularity alignment either at the start of the WA or when it comes up for renewal every 4 years. As its well known that the DUP does not want regulatory alignment with the EU long term it can't be assumed that the consensus would exits to renew this after 4 years even if it were agreed now. The DUP have said they will go along with the BJ proposal. But having the DUP agree to regulatory alignment now is is not the same as it being agreed by the NI Assembly (obviously the DUP is only one political party not a NI Government) so I would think that as a minimum the NI Assembly would need to be up and running to agree to BJ's proposals. If the NI Assembly or a NI public vote do not endorse BJ's proposal I would think that citizens would have a good case of making a legal challenge that changing the relationship between NI and the rest of the UK (and the EU) without the consent of the people was against the Good Friday Agreement, the UK constitution, and their human rights.  The steps needed to get everything sorted out before 1st Jan 2020 seem to be next to impossible. I doubt that BJ's proposal will the accepted. In my view its far too complicated to converted into a watertight legal text in a few weeks. Most agreements start from the assumption that all parties wish abide by the spirit of some easily described concept which has mutual befits. Bj's proposal is starting from the assumption that BJ will do what ever it takes to find loopholes and ways to avoid inconvenient details in whatever is signed because he does not agree with the spirit  Defining what EU law applies to food and goods is not a trivial matter as many EU rules apply to not just the goods but the means of producing the goods, transporting the goods and selling the goods, and many goods include services and many services include goods, and labour and environmental rules are part and parcel of the EU system. Some UK MPs are saying they will vote for BJ's proposals as long as other parts of the WA are also changed. So my view is that the drive to get a deal is more about signaling that any failure to get a deal will be due to some other player not the person being interviewed.       If BJ's current proposal is not agreed before 1 Jan what is likely to happen?  I don't see any alternative customs arrangement being agree before 1 Jan 2020 whatever else happens (e.g. GE, referendum, change of PM etc.)

Things fall apart fast. I don't think they can possibly agree to either of the one-sided options here within weeks of Brexit.  I cannot imagine they can A) get an agreement and B) finalize it in such a short time.  Maybe they have a framework already prepped behind the scenes but I doubt it.  It seems like a Pillar Two level (read: unanimous) agreement is required from the EU.    Ireland might want to have a say in it as well. The free trade zone concept seems handy for everyone except the UK, for whom it is a disaster, if perhaps inevitable.    I think the currency and capital markets have not come close to adjusting publicly to the immediate effects of a no deal or sloppy-deal Brexit.  I would guess the Russians are and will be heavily active in currency combat to maximize whatever they see as their interests (World domination for the Ruble).  A lot of money is going to loose a lot of value overnight.  The Pressure will be on but no one will be able to rally the complexity to solve this smaller question for a long time.   I think Europe (and Ireland and Scotland and even Wales) are going to have surprisingly intense animosity towards Britain, or The Revised City-State of Londony or whatever they change their name to, after this. The United Kingdom is dissolving itself at this point under BJ and the outcomes will be hard to predict but short term issues will use most of the competent bandwith for months. Never mind if Putin ups the chaos somehow, which I think thin he will.   My Bottom line: UK needs a whole new form of government after this. Perhaps something modeled after other obstinate isolationist island nations - Cuba comes to mind. Go home constitutional monarchy, you are drunk.

This is subject to the assumption the current UK government under PM Johnson remains in power.

Northern Ireland political and constitutional position is fraught with complexity  - despite simplistic arguments and rallying calls of politicians there remain irreconcilable red-lines between the Uk and EU.
Politicians know this - hence the backstop argument which in itself is a fudge designed to postpone resolution of the  problem.
The upshot is that this is a question that cannot be easily resolved within the timeframe put forward by the question.

The question specifically says "agreement....after any Brexit transition period". It seems unlikely that the UK and EU will have agreed anything by the end of this year. A No Deal Brexit would not be an agreement on the NI customs territory. An Extension to A50 is unlikely to have lead to an agreement on this question, no would a UK GE. A UK referendum could not be held by the end of the year so that could not lead to an agreement on this question. 
Even if a Brexit deal is signed before November the permanent status of the NI customs territory would not be agreed until after the Future Trade Agreement, which would be years away.

The UK will leave the EU on 1st November 2019 regardless of a deal. A solution to the Irish backstop will either be found or the UK border solutuion with the EU will incorporate NI in the same way that it will operate at Dover.

It's ironic that a portion of the Brexit vote in 2016 responded to immigration problems which have since abated and, now, for those migrants who don't choose Ryan Air or BA for entry, a border without passport control would make migration easier. I find it hard to imagine either EU or GB accepting separation without passport control at the border. And DUP would prefer a return to The Troubles than to be treated differently from England.

There is nowhere near a UK Parliamentary majority for any EU withdrawal agreement that divides the UK's customs territory, 1% is a generous "never rule out the impossible" probability. The question's specification of "agreement" means that all the "no deal" probabilities go into the "No" category here. I do think with skilled negotiation (about a 20% chance of that happening) that the "UK customs territory only" agreement could be feasible before 2020 with a vague enough promise of lots of technological checks in the far future (after a transition). The 14% is an approximation of a General Election + Labour/Remain-ish majority that acts quickly, in addition to that of a "parliamentary push" on Boris that would persuade him to accept the withdrawal agreement pretty much as-is with an indefinite backstop.

Consider the slowness, and the twists and turns of the past Brexit development, there is very little chance something substantial can happen in 2 months.    
If Brexit get cancelled, there will be no "negotiated agreement" for Norther Ireland.  So the resolution for this question would be No in the case.
So I go out on a limb to forecast nothing will happen in this time frame.

On the related question, my opinion of the most probable outcomes in UK by Halloween are to set a date for a referendum or hold an election - with a referendum the most likely consequence of the election. (Hard exit or no exit.) The clock runs out on this question before the referendum.
There's a slim chance the hard exit is carried through with by the conservatives without being stopped by a non-confidence vote (10% is generous), 
There's no chance of a new negotiation with EU, let alone passage through Parliament - or negotiation of the terms at the Irish border - despite the misleading/false posturing by Conservative leadership hopefuls.

Updating from 90/3/1/6 due to May stepping down as PM, which makes it even less likely that the UK will leave before the scheduled date of 31 Oct 2019. New PM is now supposed to take over at the end of July. Just upping "no" from 90 to 92 and taking 1% from the 2 other highest buckets.
A brexiteer mp will be elected prime minister and the question will be addressed directly. Northern Ireland is part of the United Kingdom.

There is no political will to achieve a solution. The European elections outcome will almost certainly produce a low turn out and a limited results for the main political parties. The focus for the remainder of the year will be with leadership elections and some form of renegotiation of the withdrawal agreement. We are entering a period of drift. A second referendum only add to delay.
The chances of any long-term agreement being reached by the end of the year are negligible (by definition, this excludes a no-deal Brexit, which remains a distinct possibility).

It looks like a difficult puzzle to piece together, however if they don't get it done before the end of October it looks to be chaotic.

Things change slowly, then very fast. It could be a hot summer in NI, which would really throw the Brexit negotiations into the fire. There is apparently a new, active IRA who kill people. Putting a layer of customs and trading  issues on top would be irresponsible in the extreme. Watch out for the marching season.

Asking for clarification on a fifth option if Northern Ireland is treated as a special case with customs items falling under separate agreements; some with EU, others in UK jurisdictions, depending on logistics and referendum outcome. https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/brexit-ireland-ehic-card-pay-insurance-northern-irish-coveney-europe-health-coverage-a8874861.html
I was underestimating the do nothing option

The transition period is now set to not begin until at least 1 Nov 2019. The EU has repeatedly stated that negotiations for after the transition period will not start until Brexit has happened and the transition period begun. And they have followed that promise for the almost 3 years since the vote. For this Q to not resolve as NO, the negotiations on the fate of NI post-transition would have to reach a conclusion in 2 months. Anyone following Brexit has to laugh at the prospect of even the color of customs agents' socks being agreed to in less than 2 months. If Brexit really does only happen on 31 Oct 2019, or even not before 1 Sep 2019, I regard the NO outcome as certain. Still, I'll leave 10% on the table on the odd chance that Brexit happens earlier than the deadline. Out of those 10%, put 1% on NI going under EU, which I don't think UK govt would ever go for. Then, of the remainder, let's make UK+EU customs union twice as likely as not, since I hear lots of talk of it. I do wonder how this Q will resolve if Brexit is cancelled, whether by second referendum or otherwise. On the one hand, NI will be in a joint customs union of UK+EU... on the other hand, they won't have "adopted an agreement" to that effect. I think latter is the right resolution, and more likely.

Tackling this question is a two pronged approach. There's not too many cases of customs agreements being decided in the aftermath of a state leaving a customs union while also possessing a disputed territory. In a case such as this with little precedent, what can often be helpful is looking at the signals of the actors and how they choose to posture. By comparing this with the history of an actor following through (or not) with its signalling, we can draw a rough estimate for a situation such as this. Theresa May, currently the Prime Minister of a Tory Party in the midst of a civil war, has stated openly that she will not accept a backstop deal for Northern Ireland. Indeed if any customs agreement crystallizes out of the negotiations it will likely be one that will include both countries. Any other option would be too difficult for either side to argue, and in the stalemate that has evolved out of Brexit negotiations, is unlikely to develop anywhere anytime fast (certainly, it would not be feasible within the timeframe of this poll)
The chance that no backstop is reached is also somewhat difficult to sell to hardline Brexiteers who see it as a way for the EU to essentially work through an Irish loophole. 
As it is the UK is in less of a position to argue right now. Many of Theresa May's former statements and promises have proven to fall flat, and with the Irish question the potential political risks outweigh the cries of the hardliners. Past negotiation failures have put Britain in a bad position and especially after the most recent postponements something as large as this will need to be extensively worked out, and no decisive action is feasible. https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-eu-may/separate-customs-territory-for-northern-ireland-unacceptable-pm-mays-spokeswoman-idUKKCN1N7192
https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/apr/18/how-the-irish-backstop-emerged-as-mays-brexit-nemesis
https://www.politico.eu/article/uk-cant-escape-irish-backstop-with-no-deal-brexit/

An issue that has not been considered by many in the UK: Pelosi (Speaker of House of Respresentatives) gave a speech in Dublin saying that if the UK did anything that damaged the Good Friday Agreement then forget a UK US Trade Deal. The "anything" would I believe mean if NI did not stay in the EU Customs Union/Single Market then the US House would not approve a UK US trade deal. Pelosi seems to have numbers to do this. This seems to make it difficult for the Free Trade Brexiteers to have any good argument for Brexit, as their whole pitch was that outside the EU Customs Union/Single Market the UK would be able to do hugely beneficial FTAs. As the US and EU make up half the worlds trade, if you cannot do do a FTA with either who are you going to trade with? In my view this could be as big a wake up as Suez in 1956. Then the UK, France and Israel invaded Egypt to stop it nationalising the Suez canal (which was owned by Britain and France). The UK and France did not get prior agreement from the US. After the three countries defeated Egypt the US threatened to ruin the UK economy by selling all its UK bonds if the UK did not immediately withdraw. The UK was humiliated and this event "signified the end of Great Britain as one of the World's Great Powers". If the US takes a similar strong line the over Good Friday Agreement and the Irish Border. then the UK would be forced to keep NI in the CU/SM. NI in the CU/SM while the rest of the UK was outside is unacceptable to most UK politicians. The whole UK inside the CU/SM would make Brexit pointless to most Brexiteers. So another UK humiliation, another signal that the UK is not a world power. The alternative would be to do what the UK used to do and build strong alliances so that it appeared strong thanks to these allies.        https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-usa-trade-pelosi/harm-to-irish-peace-accord-would-prevent-u-s-uk-trade-deal-post-brexit-pelosi-idUKKCN1RR20F
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suez_Crisis

No is a proxy for the extension of the Brexit deadline to 2020 (delayed Brexit or no Brexit) - possible
UK customs territory means hard borders - very unlikely given the political fall-out and parliamentary opposition
EU customs territory means UK has no say - no UK party in favour
New territory is the most likely compromise - supported by Labour, less damaging to Conservatives than other options
I am betting there actually will be no Brexit, something will give. A re-vote or stalling technique.
With memories of the “”Troubles” still present and economics dominating, a shared customs territory seems to be the most effective solution.
Recent extension gives them a little more time to come to an agreement.
The only reasonable outcome that avoids future conflict with Nothern Ireland.

The extension of A50 until the end of October makes it less likely that the Customs Territory of NI will be settled by the end of December. 
My reasoning is that the only way to keep the Irish Border open (NI with Ireland) is for them both being in one Customs territory. The only way to keep the Conservative Party together is for NI and Great Britain to be in one Customs territory. That leads to the whole UK being in the same Customs territory as the EU because the UK government will not agree to a border between the two parts of Ireland or between NI and GB. 
If A50 had been extended by a year or more there would have been time to get rid of Mrs May, and for the Conservatives to appoint a new PM and re-think how they were going to deal with Brexit and to arrive at a workable solution. 
The Conservatives are unlikely to try and replace May while local elections, and then EU elections are taking place ("vote Conservative - we are throwing out our leader" is not a vote winner.) So any new PM is not likely until June or (more likely) July. 
A new PM would presumably need a little time to come up with a Brexit plan, but my belief is that the only type of Brexit that would get support from a majority in parliament (it needing cross party support) would involve the UK staying in the EU Customs Union. As staying in the Customs Union is not what the hard Brexiteers want and not what Remainers want, I think that parliament would only support this option if the public endorsed it. So to vote thru the WA would require a commitment to a new public vote before the WA was activated. Endorsing it with a public vote would take at least 22 weeks. Even if a new PM was minded to go down this route, unless the new PM was in place in May there would be insufficient time to do this before the end of October. Which presumably means to do this would require the EU to extend A50 for longer. The most likely outcome is that the public would not endorse the version of Brexit proposed and the UK would remain in the Customs Union, if the public did endorse the Brexit proposal the UK would also stay in the Customs Union. But I don't see it happening because the A50 end date would get in the way of a public vote.
So as far as I can see the only ways that the question could be resolved (except as "No") by the end of 2019 would be by Revoking A50.
The beginning of the end. Northern Ireland gradually uniting with the Republic of Ireland in 25 years.
An arrangement has to be made. It is more likely it will be a shared arrangement than not.

It could be a blip or the start of a trend, but in the last two days at least 3 prominent Brexit promoters in the media have announced they have either changed their mind or given up on Brexit.  
(Two of them explain why in the radio clips below, the third was Claire Fox on Sky TV yesterday). https://www.lbc.co.uk/radio/presenters/james-obrien/brexiteer-divulges-reasons-behind-change-heart/
https://www.lbc.co.uk/radio/presenters/nick-ferrari/exasperated-reveals-hes-finally-given-up-brexit/

I am disappointed by the poor tactics of the Remain MPs on yesterday's indicative votes. Particularly by the The Independent Group and the LibDems and Greens. (But the SNP were not much better). They either did not vote for the "customs union" and "common market 2.0" or just chose one or the other, thereby allowing Mrs May to claim that her MV was the most popular form of Brexit. In my opinion the best tactics would be to first eliminate or at least show you want to eliminate the worst outcomes. So that was fine they did that by showing they did not want No Deal in the first batch of indicative votes. But to get want you really want you have to vote FOR some kinds of Brexit. They need to vote for the least bad forms of Brexit, to show that soft Brexit is the most popular form of Brexit and the only version of Brexit that parliament would support in the hope that the government (and EU and parliament) reject Hard Brexit as being less popular and undeliverable. Once "a Customs Union" or "Common Market 2.0" become the front runner, the argument can be made that this needs to be negotiated with the EU, so extend A50. Then when the negotiation on soft Brexit has been completed and this deal is brought back to parliament the case for holding a confirming Public Vote can be made. A good case can be made then that a soft Brexit was not what many Leave voters wanted so they might now want to vote against it and so can the Leave voters. Resulting in No Brexit. 
So in the best case scenario (for Remainers) the UK remains in the EU, in the worst case the UK leaves the EU but with what Remains would consider to be least damaging way.

Imcreasing UK customs territory because I think a no deal Brexit has become more likely. Assuming that in that case there won't be any transition period and therefore the question resolve on the date of the no deal Brexit.

Mrs May is very poor at reading the public mood, but she is right that Brexit fatigue is setting in particularity among Leave voters (see numerous opinion polls where Leave voters urge the government to "get on with it", "Just leave the EU, no deal or not".) The populist press, which only sells papers if they reflect the views of their readers is also demanding that the government get on with Brexit. So there will be a lot of pressure on MP's to speed up the process. Events over the last week show that Conservative MPs are running out of patience with Mrs May's "kick the can down the road" way of working and there is almost no appetite for allowing Mrs May to continue with whatever Brexit process emerges between now and 12th April. So it seems almost certain that whatever happens (May's version of Brexit gets through parliament - unlikely but possible; a no deal Brexit - almost impossibly; the UK keeps talking to the EU and takes part in the EU parliamentary elections - the most likely outcome) Mrs May will cease to the PM by mid-summer (and probably a lot sooner than that) and the UK will therefore have a new PM, who will be under a lot of pressure to resolve the most complex parts of Brexit quickly. Part of the most complex part of Brexit (along with the Single Market) is the Customs Union.  I see the only option on the Customs Union question that is capable of a relatively quick agreement between the EU and UK, is to remain in the existing Customs Union. Any alternative (different) version of a Customs Union between the EU and UK would  by its nature require a longer more complex period of negotiations. As the average voter has little idea what the difference between A Customs Union and THE Customs Union is and cares even less it seems to me that talk of A Customs Union is likely to be dropped. While questions of Custom Unions might excite a few voters there are a lot more voters who just want to "get on with it".  So when (as is looking almost certain) talks between the UK and EU start in October 2019 I expect it will be agreed within a few weeks that in order to solve the Irish Border Issue the Future Trade will have to include being in the Customs Union (and they will probably agree that the UK will have to be in the Single Market at least as far as goods and aquaculture is concerned).  If anyone is interested in my view of the Common Agriculture and Common Fisheries policies I would say that it would be optimistic to expect the UK to be able to leave these aspects of the EU and retain free trade on food stuffs with the EU. If there is no free trade in food with the EU, its difficult to see how the open frictionless border with the EU could work. It seems logical to me that to have an open border all goods have to be tariff free and legal on both sides of the border. If any product is subject to a different regime on the other side of a border you need to have physical checks on that border to stop smuggling. If you need to have the same conditions on either side of a border, you need to give producers either side of that border a level playing field. The Common Agriculture and Common Fisheries policies ensure a level playing field for producers. If one party has a different system then it obviously becomes much more difficult to have a level playing field (e.g. if the UK used a different subsidy system the playing field is unlikely to be level). Note: I am not saying that the CAP or CFP are great or that they should not be changed, just that any system in the UK would need to match the system in the EU.

Huge amounts of cross-border trade, the farm industry in NI depends on open borders in both directions, and nobody wants gunships in the sea off  Belfast. Also complete (deliberate?) incompetence at getting agreement of any sort together on time. Least worst is to leave things as they are.

Advanced technology cannot replace Brexit backstop, EU says EU’s deputy Brexit negotiator says technology cannot yet offer ‘alternative arrangement’ sought by UK. Hey, Britain: Forget the virtual backstop. It doesn’t exist yet.
https://www.politico.eu/article/advanced-technology-cannot-replace-backstop-eu-says-uk-brexit-withdrawal-agreement-ireland-border/

With how the UK Parliment has handled achieving a leave plan (or lack thereof), there is a high likelihood that the leave date will be extended. Not only for the UK, but the greater EU's benefit as the various actors continue to influence the idea of leave or stay. As also previously mentioned, the Good Friday Agreement virtually guarantees that even if an independent customs zone is established, it will have to be a single shared zone between both the UK and the EU.

It is now close to a 100% certainty that the UK Leaving date will have to be extended. The question is how long it will it need to be extended by. Unless Mrs May's Deal passes through parliament before a A50 extension period is agreed Its difficult to see how a short extension would be long enough. If May's deal is voted through then a 3 or 4 month extension would be possible, but  as May's Deal contains very little of a Future Trade Agreement Framework it is very likely that it will take several years to produce the FTA. If May's Deal is not approved by the UK Parliament the alternatives would probably be a lot less bespoke (e.g. a Norway+ type deal) which it is possible to turn into a agreement fairly quickly. However Mrs May is certainly not minded to go down that route, and it is likely that any deal other than May's current Deal would not emerge until after political eruptions in the UK in which one or several of these events would take place;- a change of PM, a public vote on the deal, months of stalemate, a general election, a Citizens Assembly to consider the options.   I can't see how any UK EU trade agreement that honored the Good Friday Agreement with Ireland is possible that does not end up with the Single Customs territory that includes both the EU and UK. The UK, EU and Ireland all say they will honor the Good Friday Agreement. The Good Friday Agreement guarantees that there are no checks or infrastructure on the NI Ireland border. An agreement to continue to have the EU and UK in a single Customs Territory is (almost) certain the only question in my mind is when the agreement will be delivered.   With the EU busy with Parliamentary Elections and changes to the Commission, it is difficult to see how EU/UK trade talks are likely before October 2019. Its seems very unlikely that anything but the simplest deal could be adopted by the end of December 2019.
Other outcomes are possible. The UK Parliament could Revoke A50 or a referendum that has the option of Remaining could take place and A50 could be revoked by the UK. It is not impossible that this could happen in 2019, but is unlikely

With May's Brexit deal voted down by parliament the likelihood of such a Brexit has been reduced. May's deal had almost no clarity of how the EU UK Future Trading Relationship would work, and was really just a way of exiting the EU while putting off the difficult questions to later. If parliament had approved the deal the arguments about the Irish Border, Customs Union and Single Market would have dragged on for years. By not approving the deal it becomes more likely that by the end of this year a new and clearer Future Trading Relationship will have been agreed. One reason for thinking it will be agreed this year is that all parties are getting tired of Brexit and are looking for a way to settle matters. In order to do that parliament is likely to force the government toward a clearly defined Brexit that is based on existing legal entities, rather than a totally bespoke trade deal (based on having cake and eating it). By far the most likely form of Brexit would be one in which the EU and UK remained in a single customs territory. In fact the Norway+ (Common Market 2.0) looks increasingly likely. (George Freeman MP today estimated that a majority of MPs would accept that type of Brexit).
We should find out next week what support among MPs for each type of Brexit there is. 
The public is going off the idea of Brexit altogether (YouGov poll 16th Jan 56% would prefer to Remain in the EU vs 44% still want to Leave). The impasse between May and MPs is likely to become even clearer in the next couple of weeks, and a PM who is out of step with her cabinet, her MPs and parliament can only end in one of two ways; either the PM is seen as bravely standing up for the people, or the PM is seen as stubbornly blocking those who want to resolve the impasse. My guess is May will be seen as the problem, not the solution.
The ‘both’ option is the problem and it will likely be solved or more likely not soled.
It is possible that nothing will be resolved after one year but if it is, the most workable solution that both sides would agree to is a joint venture.
This answer assumes that a Brexit deal is reached.

The EU will not even negotiate with the UK, before the Withdrawal Agreement in its present form are signed and ratified.  The is de facto 'an offer the UK can't refuse' -  but  it may not happen before 2020.
The only one that really makes sense to me is a customs territory that includes both the European Union and the United kingdom
Affects too many people in a time of high uncertainty

Due to political reasons, having a "soft" border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland is the goal for UK after Brexit.  But it is an intrinsically a hard problem to solve, otherwise a way forward would have been proposed and accepted. (You can't have your cake and eat it too).
So while having "a single customs territory that includes both the European Union and the United Kingdom" is the desirable outcome, it will take a long time and creative thinking, and therefore a 25% chance of success within a year's time frame.

Base rate: 50-50 of No deal vs. A deal. Adjusted the probability of no deal upwards to reflect the likely probability of both parties kicking the can down the road past the date of 1 January 2020. Of the options of a deal, a customs union that includes both parties seems the only possible option, as anything other than this would be vetoed by one party (both the Republic of Ireland and the British parliament have veto power over any deal). Assigned some small probabilities to the other two options (a customs territory belonging to one party) to reflect combinations of unforeseen events (the EU's decision making process changing in its current form, new elections, a new referendum, etc. etc.)
I think I may have underestimated the chances of May getting her deal through.  Her deal is for a single, temporary customs territory. I don't think this will get through, but it may.
Positions are too entrenched for a deal. Most likely scenario is a hard brexit.

An example of the lack of practical planning for the possibility of the UK leaving the EU Customs Area and Single Market is that one port that would be expected to take more freight is Poole, Dorset. Assuming that the port facilities can cope with more ferries, each requiring ten times more checks that are needed for EU to EU freight, the question becomes where are all these extra roll-on/roll-off trucks going to take their loads and how are they going to get there? Dorset is a county with no motorways at all. A glance at a map shows that the main road north from Poole is the A350. Its true that this eventually links up with the M4 motorway, but that is only after traveling for 60 miles (100km) on a road that is in several places only wide enough for vehicles to proceed in one direction at a time, as it winds up and down hills between pretty villages (when the trucks are not passing through). It normally takes over 2 hours to drive the 60 miles in a car but often it can take 3 or 4 hours when container trucks are on the road because they tend to be too big to get around the bends in the villages.  Alternate routes are a lot further on congested rural roads. 
If expanding capacity at other ports will be needed post Brexit, not only do the ports need to be rebuild but the UK's road network needs to be rebuilt. 
I hope the Brexiteers have factored in the all the infrastructure costs.
Seems to me that this is the hardest part of the existing Brexit negotiation. I can't imagine it will be easier to figure out while negotiating the much more complex deal.

IK is a strong and an old democratic state, it will no allow a piece of its soil to let it go. The only odd I see is related to the Agreement of Good Friday of 1998, but I am not sure Britons will give up to substantive sovereignty on northern Ireland.

In this related forecast: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/800096 , I put the probability of a Brexit with deal at 65% (35% as scheduled at the end of March, 30% delayed). I did not specify how long I think the delay might be, but have to assume that if Brexit is delayed, it might be delayed past the end date of this question, which I assume would resolve as "No". Since the Brexit deal would come with the backstop agreement, and I assume in that case the question would resolve as "a single customs territory...", I arrive at 50% as a bit less than 65% for that bucket. The almost equally probable scenario I see as no agreement before the end date. I don't see an agreement to have Northern Ireland on UK custom territory only within the time frame, because there would need to be some major marketing for this solution. If by a snap election or vote of no confidence, the government does not rely on the DUP any more, I see a very small chance that there might be a solution with Northern Ireland on EU custom's territory.

I don't see any way to resolve the issue other than keeping the status quo for as long as possible, which will probably mean punting the issue for at least another 12 months.  The one clarification that I would like to see though is if the answer would be resolved as "No" or "Yes, a single customs territory.." if the UK holds a second referendum and votes to rescind Article 50.

The UK CT only would be contrary to the GoodFriday Agreement. To do this really mean getting rid of the GF agreement and that would be a major problem.
The EU CT only would cause significant domestic political problems. many Leave voters and MPs would hate to make NI and Ireland closer than NI and GB would be. If NI was allowed to have a different post-Brexit relationship with the EU then Scotland would demand that they also remain in a Customs Territory with the EU.
Mrs May likes to kick the can down the road. If her Brexit deal gets through Parliament or not the fact is that no post Brexit trade deal negotiations has yet started. Because of EU elections its unlikely that any serious future relations negotiations will start before October 2019, which is not time to have an agreement by 1 Jan 2020.
If Mrs May is replaced (or parliament takes control) it is looking as if a referendum will almost certainly be needed so that voters can chose what Brexit outcome they want. It is quite possible that a referendum could take place by October 2019 and that (going by current opinion polls) the most like result would be to Remain in the EU or possibly to remain in the EEA+Customs Union. In either case the UK would remain in a Single Customs Territory with the EU. 
I think its close to 100% likely that the outcome will be the Single Customs Territory, the doubt is when that would be agreed.  My feeling is that May (and Corbyn) will try and delay the inevitable most other people will try and get Brexit resolved. So far May has succeeded in avoiding taking any decision so I would not rule out that she will cling on and drag it out for another year.

I think it is unlikely that there will be a signed agreement where NI is only in the UK customs territory, mostly because it would require Ireland to join the UK customs union in order to keep the Good Friday agreement (which the EU seems to be a guarantor of, making my life more complicated) There is a good chance of the UK not getting its act together even in 2019, so we cannot discount No. Right now I don't see how the Good Friday agreement can be kept, NI staying part of the UK and Ireland staying part of the EU, without the UK staying the EU, so from a fundamental point the last option seems the most likely (though I have no idea how to get there). The alternative would be that NI elects to join Ireland and as such the EU. There are a number of technical questions for this question:
- How will a no-Brexit scenario be scored? I assume as No
- How will a Brexit-in-name-only scenario be scored? I assume as "in both", but could also be "in EU" (if UK doesn't get its own customs zone)
- How would the May-deal be scored? I assume as "in both" And fundamental questions:
- Will that be decided in 2019 or will it drag out longer?
- What are the wishes of the UK government? This question ought to be fun, but probably bad for the score :D
